awd_titl_txt: Effects of Financial Sanctions in the Criminal Justice System
awd_abstract_narration:
The use of legal financial obligations, colloquially referred to as financial sanctions, imposed on individuals who come into contact with the criminal justice system is widespread and growing in the U.S. criminal justice system. These fees and fines could generate serious social and economic consequences, particularly among low-income populations who are unable to pay them on time. These costs may outweigh the intended benefits, such as deterring crime, compelling court appearances, and making restitution, of financial sanctions. The goal of this project is to evaluate the economic and social consequences of financial sanctions in the justice system on affected individuals and their families. Since fines vary widely across jurisdictions and stages of the justice system to which they are applied, this is a multi-state project that will leverage multiple natural experiments across a variety of states to document potential heterogeneous impacts and understand mediating channels.

To achieve this, researchers will use the Criminal Justice Administrative Record System (CJARS), combined with individual-level demographic and economic data held by the U.S. Census Bureau. Furthermore, the project will link individuals to their family members to assess spillover effects on their spouses and children, significantly improving the current understanding of financial sanctions. To measure the impact of financial, researchers will leverage natural experiments from the enactment of a variety of policies on different financial sanctions across various states, using a sharp regression discontinuity for causal identification. Outcomes of interest are labor market outcomes and criminal behavior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to estimate the impact of financial sanctions in the U.S. criminal justice system on the lives of those who have such penalties levied against them. A variety of short and long-term outcomes were studied, including employment, recidivism, household expenditures, spousal spillovers, and other self-reported measures of well-being.

To study the impact of financial sanctions on outcomes of individuals involved in the justice system, a total of nine discrete policy changes that occurred in fives states (Florida, Michigan, North Carolina, Texas, and Wisconsin) were leveraged. This created the opportunity to design a series of regression discontinuity designs to study variation in outcomes across the time period surrounding the policy changes. These regression discontinuity designs capture a range of enforcement levels and institutional environments, providing robust causal evidence and external validity.

Results indicated consistent, robust evidence of precise null effects on the population studied. The policy changes that changed fines and fees resulted in no statistically significant nor economically meaningful changes in either annual convictions, annual earnings, or average monthly housing costs when pooling across all sub-experiments. For example, results indicated that the average response to fine increases was 0.004 additional crimes per year (increase 1.9%), $89 lower earnings per year (decrease 0.6%), and -$6 in housing costs (decrease 0.6%). Additionally, null effects were found for the impact of financial sanctions on the outcomes of romantic partners of individuals that received financial sanctions.

This research project provided numerous training and professional development opportunities by giving a diverse set of research staff (e.g., research assistants, graduate students, post-doctoral research fellows, project managers) experiences across a wide range of research activities. At the time this was written, a manuscript summarizing the findings from the study was conditionally accepted at the American Economic Review: Insights.
